title_full: FSISUS01-BP01 Select a Region with lower environmental impact that meets your financial services industry business and compliance considerations
title: Select a Region with lower environmental impact that meets your financial services industry business and compliance considerations
description: Shortlist potential Regions based on data security and privacy issues, regulatory compliance requirements, operational efficiency, local data sovereignty concerns, and services that optimize sustainability. Select Regions using market-based or location-based methods aligned with sustainability guidelines. Wherever possible, choose a Region that provides better than 95% renewable energy using market-based method and low grid carbon intensity.
outcome: Improved sustainability posture through selection of Regions with lower environmental impact while meeting compliance requirements

title_full: FSISUS02-BP01 Run workloads and store restricted data in required country and unrestricted in sustainable Region selected by following SUS01 guidance
title: Run workloads and store restricted data in required country and unrestricted in sustainable Region selected by following SUS01 guidance
description: Review data sovereignty regulations and identify workloads and data that can be run in sustainable Regions. Separate data and processing to take advantage of data and processes using lower carbon resources where data residency is not required, while accessing higher carbon resources when data residency is a requirement. Choose a sustainable Region following FSISUS01 guidance and run workloads using more sustainable Regions when not restricted by specific locations.
outcome: Compliance with data sovereignty regulations while optimizing for sustainability by segregating workloads appropriately

title_full: FSISUS03-BP01 Select Regions that offer services required by financial services organizations and hardware that maximizes the reduction of your carbon footprint
title: Select Regions that offer services required by financial services organizations and hardware that maximizes the reduction of your carbon footprint
description: Develop a list of all services required by financial services workloads. Select a Region using guidance from FSISUS01-BP01. Develop a cross-reference of sustainable Regions chosen according to the services offered within each Region as well as the variety and types of sustainable hardware offered in the Region.
outcome: Optimized Region selection that balances service availability with sustainability considerations and hardware efficiency

title_full: FSISUS04-BP01 Actively manage each business function and the allocation and configuration of resources
title: Actively manage each business function and the allocation and configuration of resources
description: Use Amazon ECS Spot for non-critical workloads such as end-of-month reconciliations. Use Amazon EC2 Dedicated Hosts queues for priority jobs such as order initiation. Use Amazon ECR Lifecycle Policies for ephemeral ETL data. Develop architecture strategies that use built-in queueing and buffering to offload non-critical tasks.
outcome: Improved resource efficiency through targeted allocation of resources based on workload criticality

title_full: FSISUS04-BP02 FSI workloads serve the highest common denominator of application demands
title: FSI workloads serve the highest common denominator of application demands
description: Break down a system into component parts to allow for a fine-grained view of resource consumption and trade-offs to balance SLAs against sustainability goals. Prioritize at organizational, SCP/OU, account, resource/tag, and job levels. Use tags to group and aggregate management and reporting of resources. Implement graceful termination of non-critical jobs and active workload management.
outcome: Enhanced sustainability through granular prioritization and workload management across organizational levels

title_full: FSISUS05-BP01 Analyze network access patterns to identify the places that your customers are connecting from
title: Analyze network access patterns to identify the places that your customers are connecting from
description: Remove redundant layers and redirects. Use pagination and local caching mechanisms to reduce data movement. Consider separating workloads that serve different users. Analyze network access patterns to optimize network traffic routing and minimize unnecessary data transfer.
outcome: Reduced network traffic and energy consumption through optimized access patterns and data movement

title_full: FSISUS05-BP02 Avoid common architectural misconfigurations
title: Avoid common architectural misconfigurations
description: Identify and remediate poor architectural choices such as hairpinning traffic through on-premises networks, redundant layers of control, and serving both OLAP and OLTP workloads from the same database. Assess workflows for varying demand over time and select scalable AWS services. Provide sufficient failover resources for partial outages.
outcome: Eliminated architectural inefficiencies that generate excessive and unnecessary data movement

title_full: FSISUS06-BP01 Actively monitor your FSI resource usage
title: Actively monitor your FSI resource usage
description: Monitor and analyze financial services usage patterns to minimize resource usage. Identify services that are not required to be operational at all times or that can be scaled based on user access patterns. Remove underutilized software modules. Minimize average resource demand using automatic scaling, serverless transaction processing, or shutting down resources during low usage. Use queue-driven architectures and On-Demand Instance workers.
outcome: Reduced resource consumption through active monitoring and scaling based on actual demand patterns

title_full: FSISUS07-BP01 Optimize your batch processing systems
title: Optimize your batch processing systems
description: Queue up several requests together that do not require immediate processing. Increase serialization to flatten utilization across pipeline. Modify capacity of individual components to prevent idling resources. Create buffers and establish rate limiting to smooth consumption of external services. Use most efficient available hardware and services. Schedule jobs during times with lowest carbon intensity when possible.
outcome: Optimized batch processing efficiency with reduced resource consumption and improved sustainability

title_full: FSISUS08-BP01 Use event-driven architecture
title: Use event-driven architecture
description: Implement event-driven architecture using pub/sub or pull mechanisms instead of polling approaches to avoid idling of resources. If event-driven architecture is not possible, modify capacity of individual components to prevent idling downstream resources. Avoid polling APIs or queues; instead have components subscribe to events or be notified of changes.
outcome: Reduced idle resource consumption through event-driven architecture patterns

title_full: FSISUS09-BP01 Monitor and optimize areas of code that are the most compute resource-intensive
title: Monitor and optimize areas of code that are the most compute resource-intensive
description: Use CodeGuru and Amazon Q Developer to optimize code efficiency. Choose the most efficient OS and programming languages for your code. Remove unnecessary code such as modules that perform sorting or formatting. Focus optimization efforts on the most compute-intensive areas of the codebase.
outcome: Improved code efficiency and reduced resource consumption through targeted optimization

title_full: FSISUS10-BP01 Balance your data performance requirements against its carbon footprint
title: Balance your data performance requirements against its carbon footprint
description: Define proxy metrics to monitor business outcomes in relation to environmental impact. Use the right S3 storage class based on data performance requirements. Configure S3 lifecycle policies to transition objects between storage classes. For fixed-size storage systems, monitor available space and automate allocation. Avoid backup of unnecessary data; only back up data with business value or compliance requirements.
outcome: Optimized storage efficiency through appropriate storage class selection and lifecycle policies

title_full: FSISUS10-BP02 Separate data into hot, warm, cold storage
title: Separate data into hot, warm, cold storage
description: Implement data classification policy to understand criticality and choose appropriate energy-efficient storage tier. Evaluate data characteristics and access patterns including data type, growth, durability, and access frequency. Group data into classification tiers based on criticality, confidentiality, integrity, and availability requirements.
outcome: Right-sized storage allocation through tiered data classification reducing overall energy consumption

title_full: FSISUS11-BP01 Use processed data to reduce your storage footprint
title: Use processed data to reduce your storage footprint
description: Process raw data before storage, then store only the results to reduce storage requirements. Unless raw data retention is required for compliance, purge raw data automatically after processing to reduce storage footprint. This approach reduces redundant data storage from streaming sources and multiple data sources.
outcome: Significantly reduced storage requirements through strategic data processing and purging

title_full: FSISUS12-BP01 Set appropriate instance usage goals that reflect your sustainability requirements
title: Set appropriate instance usage goals that reflect your sustainability requirements
description: Instance utilization goals differ by company but can use common metrics like carbon emissions and energy consumption. Set measurable goals like ideal utilization percentage or maximum idle instance threshold within the context of your business. These goals provide guidance and justification for organizational decisions toward sustainable usage.
outcome: Established measurable sustainability targets for instance utilization across the organization

title_full: FSISUS12-BP02 Track your overall process in achieving your goals
title: Track your overall process in achieving your goals
description: Set a regular cadence with stakeholders to identify current state and create action plans to iterate. Use AWS Customer Carbon Footprint Tool to report emissions from AWS usage following GHG Protocol standards. Analyze changes in emissions over time and forecast how emissions change across sustainability journey.
outcome: Tracked progress and iterative improvements toward sustainability goals

title_full: FSISUS12-BP03 Monitor your individual instance performance metrics
title: Monitor your individual instance performance metrics
description: Establish process to monitor individual instances to use optimization approaches: using only what you need and right-sizing. Use Amazon CloudWatch to benchmark instance performance with default and custom metrics. Use IsIdle metric for EMR to identify termination candidates. Run processor-specific performance tests. Track supply to demand with EC2 Auto Scaling to keep policies dynamic.
outcome: Optimized instance utilization through continuous monitoring and right-sizing decisions

title_full: FSISUS13-BP01 Do not complete a customer transaction in the shortest time when not required by end users
title: Do not complete a customer transaction in the shortest time when not required by end users
description: If workloads do not have time-sensitive requirements, run them during times of public demand. This distributes energy consumption to flatten resource demand curve and reduce provisioned capacity. Evaluate workload requirements to assess if this adjustment is feasible.
outcome: Reduced peak demand and energy consumption through workload distribution over time

title_full: FSISUS13-BP02 Introduce jitter to your scheduled tasks
title: Introduce jitter to your scheduled tasks
description: Distribute scheduled tasks to run at random times during hour or throughout day to minimize peak demand spikes. Avoid using same start minute across scheduled tasks. Stagger job start times to avoid load spikes. For grid computing, spread intensive workloads and run fewer instances to maximize renewable energy availability. Ensure proper fault tolerance as restarting can increase launch time and energy consumption.
outcome: Flattened workload demand curve reducing provisioned capacity and energy consumption

title_full: FSISUS14-BP01 Use instances with higher energy efficiency
title: Use instances with higher energy efficiency
description: AWS Graviton-based instances use up to 60% less energy than comparable EC2 instances. Support multi-architecture images to increase flexibility and opportunity to use more sustainable hardware. Adopt multi-architecture image support for workloads to build different architectures and operating systems from same source.
outcome: Significantly reduced energy consumption through adoption of energy-efficient Graviton instances

title_full: FSISUS14-BP02 Design applications that can use different Amazon EC2 instance types
title: Design applications that can use different Amazon EC2 instance types
description: Design flexible workloads that can use various instance types rather than relying on few inflexible ones. Flexible workloads are ideal for Spot Instances which is more energy efficient than On-Demand. Use EC2 spare capacity with Spot to extract same value and increase overall resource utilization.
outcome: Improved energy efficiency through flexible workload design enabling Spot Instance usage

title_full: FSISUS14-BP03 Adopt a serverless, event-driven architecture
title: Adopt a serverless, event-driven architecture
description: Use serverless, event-driven architecture to maximize overall resource utilization. Serverless removes requirement to run and maintain physical servers. Cost and resource usage correlate with actual usage level increasing efficiency. For financial simulations, test with cluster of instances to assess performance and floating-point accuracy across processors.
outcome: Maximized resource utilization and cost efficiency through serverless architecture adoption

title_full: FSISUS15-BP01 Minimize the bit count while maintaining precision
title: Minimize the bit count while maintaining precision
description: For intensive financial simulations, test the number of bits required for floating point precision. Consider reducing bits by selecting different formats including bfloat16 supported by AWS Graviton. Use floating point quantization to represent numbers using lower bit-count integers or floating point without significant accuracy loss. Replace 32-bit parameters with half-precision (16 bit), bfloat16 (16 bit), or 8-bit integers.
outcome: Reduced resource usage and energy consumption through optimized floating-point precision

title_full: FSISUS16-BP01 Verify that all development resources are dedicated to an active project or team
title: Verify that all development resources are dedicated to an active project or team
description: Establish regular review of all test resources to identify orphaned development resources from cancelled or uncommenced projects. Mitigate wasted development resources by ensuring all test environments and resources are actively used by projects or teams. Eliminate unused resources to reduce unnecessary environmental impact.
outcome: Eliminated wasted development resources through regular review and cleanup processes
